variant.question: Regarding pavement strength, the abbreviation ACN stands for..

options.text: Aircraft Classification Number.
Aircraft Code Number.
Aerodrome Classification Number.
Aerodrome Code Number.

variant.question: According to ICAO Annex 14, the bearing strength of a pavement intended for aircraft of apron (ramp) mass equal to or less than 5700 kg shall be made available by reporting which information?

options.text: The maximum allowable tire pressure category or value and evaluation method.
The maximum allowable aircraft mass and maximum allowable tire pressure.
The maximum allowable aircraft mass and subgrade strength category.
The maximum allowable tire pressure category and subgrade strength category.

variant.question: The Pavement Classification System (ACN-PCN), for an aircraft under 5 700 kg:

options.text: Lists the types of aircraft permitted to use that pavement.
Is used in the normal way.
The Pavement Classification System is not applicable to aircraft under 5700 kg.
Is used for grass strips.

variant.question: Regarding the bearing strength of aprons, runways, and taxiways, the abbreviation PCN stands for..

options.text: Platform Code Number.
Pavement Classification Number.
Platform Classification Number.
Pavement Code Number.

variant.question: Regarding pavement strength, you are at the apron prior to taxi-out and assess your aircraft ACN to be 45\. – According to the aerodrome chart, the reported PCN for the taxiway you have to take is 50\. – Are you allowed to taxi on that taxiway?

options.text: No, a specific waiver from the aerodrome operator is needed.
Yes, but this will result in an overload pavement operation.
Yes, use of the taxiway is allowed.
No, the bearing capacity of the taxiway is too low.
